awd_titl_txt: ICES: Small: Socio-Technical Design of Crowdfunding  Websites
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore some technical problems in the area of "crowdfunding:" inducing members of the public to contribute small amounts of money at a time to fund projects.  Crowdfunding web sites are an instance of a commonly studied problem called a "matching marketplace:" a central place where two types of people come to be matched according to some criteria.   Other examples of this are job websites, where employers and employees come to be matched (find jobs), and online dating sites.  Crowdfunding exhibits a "complementarity:" a project cannot start until enough people donate money.  One person's donation is not enough to support a project, but if a person waits for others to donate first, valuable projects may be left unfunded. Many real-world matching marketplaces involve complementarities, including couples finding jobs together and a project manager trying to put together a team that works well together.

This project brings together ideas from both computer science and economics.   Both disciplines study matching problems, but neither has found a completely satisfactory solution in the presence of complementarities.  In economics, the most common solution is a "deferred acceptance" mechanism, which breaks down when dealing with complementarities.   Computer scientists frequently use "recommender systems" that make recommendations to people to help improve matches.  But it isn't even clear what should be recommended when there are complementarities.  This research will develop an understanding of the role of complementarities in both of these types of solutions, and apply insights across fields to design better methods of matching.

The project will test these ideas in the real world by developing a crowdfunding system. This system will provide a test bed for new algorithms and mechanisms.  It will also support a vibrant community of students by helping them to fund small creative projects that develop important skills. Crowdfunding is increasingly being applied to fund high-quality professional journalism (on sites such as Spot.Us), and improved crowdfunding systems have the potential to be a new funding source for this struggling industry.  This research project will also train both undergraduate and graduate students in the conduct of interdisciplinary research.

por.por_cntn:
Websites like Spot.Us and Kickstarter support a novel method of funding small projects known as “crowdfunding”: individual donors directly contribute funds to projects that they want to support.  As a online marketplace, though, crowdfunding websites are inefficient: donors prefer to only donate to project ideas that are receiving enough contributions from others. Therefore, each donor's preferences depend on the behavior of others. This project investigated ways that crowdfunding websites can be designed to create better outcomes.


One major investigation involved the all-or-nothing rule in crowdfunding.  Websites like Kickstarter are all-or-nothing; project creators specify a goal and a deadline, and if they receive enough donations to meet their goal by the deadline then they get the money.  If they do not, then the money is returned to the donors.   Other websites, like IndieGoGo, allow project creators to keep all donations regardless if the goal was met.


We found that the all­-or-­nothing return rule does indeed lead people to donate more money to the system. It does this by making people more willing to donate to high-­risk projects, where risk is the specifically the risk of not achieving enough funding. However, due to an issue we identify as spread, these increased donations do not actually lead to greater levels of market efficiency; donors spread out their donations over more projects, leaving less money for any individual project. Since projects only succeed if they cross a funding threshold, spreading out donations leads to more projects failing despite receiving non­trivial donations. Direct donation (no return rule) induces people to implicitly coordinate their donations.


The all­-or-­nothing also affects project creators. Project creators find that it is easier to fund popular projects with broad bases of support than it is to fund niche projects that have fewer but more fervent supporters. This can lead to a bias in the projects that are created on a crowdfunding website if it always requires the use of the return rule; idosyncratic niche projects will be eliminated in favor of more broadly appealing projects.


Crowdfunding websites are organized as a series of small­ish "projects", where each project has its own independent description and funding goal. We found that people make significantly larger donations (over 2x) when they know that their donation will complete a project by meeting its funding goal. Furthermore, people who do this are more likely to return and donate to other projects, and future donations are likely to be larger. Our empirical estimates from Donors Choose suggest that increases in donation amounts due to completing projects is responsible for at least 15% of the donation dollars received by the crowdfunding website. Organizing crowdfunding requests as a series of small­ish projects enables crowdfunding websites to take advantage of this completion bias to receive more money.


Crowdfunding donors focus their donations at two specific times during the lifecycle of a project: at the beginning of the project and at the end. Donations at the beginnig have a larger effect, as they encourage people to donate more in the future. Donations at the end, though, often make the project by bringing the project up to its goal.


Crowdfunding donors usually end up focusing on a single project. However, they often look at other related projects to understand what is a "normal" amount of donations for a project to have received. If their focal project looks bad relative to the comparison projects, then they are less likely to donate. This means that the success of other, unrelated projects might have a surprisingly strong effect on whether any given project is able to raise its money.


Project creators, such as teachers on Donors Choose, learn over time from their past successes and failures. They adjust the amount they ask for over time to be more reasonable. However, initial over-ambitious project creators who ask for too much can easily get discouraged and are less likely to return to try again (and learn) than less-ambitious creators.


Additionally, this project trained 4 PhD students and 9 undergraduate students in how to conduct interdisciplinary research.   1 PhD student and 4 undergradaute students were women, and 1 undergraduate student was African American, which are members of underrepresented groups in STEM research like this. As part of this project, we released the source code for the experiment system we created (https://github.com/rwash/crowdfunding-experiment ) and for a crowdfunding system we developed (https://github.com/rwash/contribute ) under open source licenses.
